snp4.7.translated_title: To Tissametteyya on the Dangers of Sex
snp4.7.blurb: The drawbacks of falling away from the celibate life.

snp2.8.blurb: A good teacher, like a good boatman, is one who knows firsthand how to cross to the further shore.

snp5.16.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Mogharāja
snp5.16.blurb: How should one view the world so as to escape the king of Death?

snp4.2.blurb: Those who remain attached to the body, to sensuality, and to their sense of “mine” will have a hard time freeing themselves from fear of death and from further becoming.

snp4.15.blurb: The Buddha speaks in poignant terms of the saṁvega that led him to leave the household life. He concludes with recommendations for practice and a description of the person who has attained the goal of true peace and security.

snp2.9.blurb: The attitudes and behavior that enable one best to learn and benefit from the Dhamma.

snp1.3.blurb: If you can’t find a good teacher, it’s better to wander alone.

snp5.7.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Upasīva
snp5.7.blurb: What support should one hold on to in order to cross over the flood of craving? Can an awakened person be described?

snp4.11.blurb: The Buddha is questioned on the source of quarrels and disputes, and on the highest level of spiritual attainment.

snp1.11.blurb: Victory over the defilements through contemplation of the unattractiveness of the body.

snp5.11.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Kappa
snp5.11.blurb: What is the island above the flood of the great danger of birth?

snp1.9.translated_title: The Buddha Teaches Sātāgira and Hemavata the Native Spirits
snp1.9.blurb: The Buddha explains to a yakkha how one crosses over the flood.

snp3.5.blurb: What are the qualities of a recipient that produce the most merit from a gift?

snp2.14.blurb: The proper code of conduct for lay followers of the Dhamma.

snp5.13.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Bhadrāvudha
snp5.13.blurb: Bhadrāvudha asks the Buddha: How did you come to know the Dhamma?

snp5.6.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Dhotaka
snp5.6.blurb: How can one become freed of all doubt?

snp5.19.translated_title: Preserving the Way to the Beyond
snp5.19.blurb: Piṅgiya, after becoming a non-returner, explains to his former teacher his devotion to the Buddha.

snp2.13.blurb: The sort of person who, having gone forth, is fit to wander through the world.

snp4.13.translated_title: The Longer Discourse on Arrayed For Battle
snp4.13.blurb: How to maintain freedom in a world full of disputes.

snp3.12.blurb: Not all dualities are misleading. This sutta teaches ways to contemplate the duality of the origination and cessation of stress and suffering so as to reach awakening.

snp5.10.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Todeyya
snp5.10.blurb: How to recognize an emancipated person.

snp3.1.blurb: The young Bodhisatta (Buddha-to-be), soon after leaving home, explains why he refuses King Bimbisāra’s offer of a position in his court.

snp3.9.blurb: Is one worthy of respect because of one’s birth, or because of one’s actions?

snp4.3.blurb: Freedom isn’t to be found by boasting of your precepts and practices or by debating your views.

snp5.9.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Hemaka
snp5.9.blurb: How do you cross over entanglements in the world?

snp4.5.blurb: The conceit that comes from clinging to practices or views—even if they’re supreme—is a fetter preventing full freedom.

snp-parayanavagga.translated_title: The Chapter on the Way to the Beyond
snp-parayanavagga.blurb: This is perhaps the most sophisticated and moving poetic composition in early Buddhism. It begins with a brahmin, suffering an unwanted curse, who sends his students to seek the Buddha. At the end of a long journey they ask questions, the nature of which indicate their subtle philosophy and deep meditation. It concludes with an emotional declaration of faith and determination.

snp4.8.blurb: The drawbacks of engaging in debates, for winners and losers alike.

snp1.1.blurb: One who advances far along the path sloughs off the near shore and far, like a snake who sloughs off its skin.

snp.blurb: The “Group of Discourses” contains 74 mostly short texts in verse or mixed prose and verse, arranged in five chapters. This contains some of the most beloved texts in popular Buddhism, such as the Ratana, Maṅgala, and Mettā Suttas, which are known to all Theravada Buddhists and recited as uplifting and protective chants at auspicious ceremonies. The collection as a whole is somewhat late; it is not found in northern scriptures, and some portions, such as the opening verses of the Nālaka Sutta, belong to the latest strata of the early texts. Nevertheless, certain sections—the “Rhinoceros Horn”, the “Chapter of the Eights”, and the “Way to the Beyond”—appear to have existed before being gathered into the collection, and are regarded as early. While the collection as a whole has no counterpart elsewhere, several portions have parallels in Chinese or Sanskrit.

snp2.4.blurb: A list of the types of skillful behavior that give blessings and protection.

snp1.8.blurb: The practice of developing universal goodwill: the practices that form a foundation for the practice, the attitude of universal goodwill itself, and the steps that lead from goodwill to awakening.

snp3.4.translated_title: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarika on the Sacrificial Cake
snp3.4.blurb: A brahman questions the Buddha to see if the latter deserves to receive the cake resulting from his sacrifice.

snp5.18.translated_title: Homage to the Way to the Beyond
snp5.18.blurb: The questions and events are summarized.

snp5.17.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Piṅgiya
snp5.17.blurb: Alarmed by the deterioration of his aging body, Piṅgiya asks the Buddha how to conquer birth and decay.

snp1.4.blurb: The Buddha answers a farmer who claims that monks do no useful work and so don’t deserve to eat.

snp3.2.blurb: Māra attempts to dissuade the Bodhisatta from his path.

snp2.7.blurb: How brahmans, through greed, abandoned the good principles of their ancestors.

snp2.1.blurb: The many treasures to be found in the Triple Gem.

snp5.15.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Posala
snp5.15.blurb: How to develop insight after mastering the perception of nothingness.

snp5.4.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Puṇṇaka
snp5.4.blurb: Birth and aging can be overcome, not through sacrificial rituals, but through training the mind to go beyond perturbation.

snp5.1.blurb: A brahman teacher sends his students to the Buddha to see if the latter is truly awakened.

snp2.11.blurb: Rāhula reflects on the teachings he received from his father, the Buddha.

snp5.14.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Udaya
snp5.14.blurb: How to reach unbinding and bring consciousness to a halt.

snp-mahavagga.blurb: Twelve longer poems that expand into sometimes legendary narrative. The first two discourses and the Nalaka Sutta offer early glimpses at crucial episodes in the Buddha’s life. While some of these poems are found elsewhere in the canon, the Dvayatānupassanā offers a unique perspective on dependent origination and other topics typically found in prose texts.

snp4.12.translated_title: The Shorter Discourse on Arrayed For Battle
snp4.12.blurb: If the truth is one, how should a person behave in a world where many different truths are taught?

snp5.12.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Jatukaṇṇī
snp5.12.blurb: How does one abandon birth and aging?

snp1.5.blurb: Four different types of contemplatives and how to recognize them.

snp4.9.blurb: Māgandiya offers the Buddha his daughter in marriage. The Buddha refuses and further subdues Māgandiya’s pride by describing a state of peace that Māgandiya doesn’t understand.

snp3.6.blurb: A sutta dating from early in the Buddha’s teaching career. A wanderer, disappointed in the teachings he has received from other teachers, approaches the Buddha with his questions.

snp1.10.blurb: A yakkha challenges the Buddha with riddles and threatens to “hurl out his mind, rip open his heart, or hurl him across the River Ganges” if he doesn’t solve the riddles to the yakkha’s satisfaction.

snp2.3.blurb: How to recognize a true friend.

snp4.6.blurb: Life is short. Possessiveness brings grief. Freedom comes from abandoning any sense of “mine.”

snp3.10.translated_title: To Kokāliya on the Results of Slander
snp3.10.blurb: A follower of Devadatta slanders Ven. Sāriputta and Ven. Moggallāna and, after suffering a painful disease, falls into hell. The sutta then gives a graphic description of the sufferings awaiting him there.

snp4.14.blurb: The attitudes and behavior of a monk training for the sake of total release.

snp2.10.blurb: Get up! Don’t let the opportunity for practice pass you by.

snp1.7.blurb: Being an outcaste is a matter of behavior, not birth.

snp-culavagga.blurb: Thirteen diverse poems similar to the previous chapter.

snp5.8.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Nanda
snp5.8.blurb: Who deserves to be called a sage? Who has crossed over birth and aging?

snp1.2.blurb: A poetic dialogue contrasting the wealth and security of lay life with the wealth and security of a person who has lived the renunciate life to its culmination. If you have trouble relating to someone like Dhaniya who measures his wealth in cattle, then when reading this poem substitute stocks and bonds for cows and bulls, and economic downturn for rain.

snp1.12.blurb: The characteristics of the ideal sage, who finds happiness and security in living the solitary life. (This sutta is apparently one of the series of passages that King Asoka recommended for study and reflection by all practicing Buddhists.)

snp5.3.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Tissametteyya
snp5.3.blurb: Who in the world is truly contented, truly free, truly a great person?

snp4.4.blurb: How to avoid the trap of letting go of one thing only to cling to something more subtle.

snp5.5.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Mettagū
snp5.5.blurb: How does one cross the flood of birth and old age, sorrow and grief?

snp1.6.blurb: The various actions and attitudes that lead to spiritual decline.

snp3.11.blurb: A sutta in two parts. The first part gives an account of events soon after the birth of the Bodhisatta. The second part describes the way of the sage.

snp2.5.blurb: Another yakkha challenges the Buddha with riddles and threatens to “hurl out his mind, rip open his heart, or hurl him across the River Ganges” if he doesn’t solve the riddles to the yakkha’s satisfaction.

snp4.16.blurb: When a monk, disaffected with the world, takes up the life of seclusion, what fears should he overcome? What dangers should he beware of? How should he train to blow away the impurities in his heart?

snp5.2.translated_title: The Questions of the Student Ajita
snp5.2.blurb: A brahman questions the Buddha about mindfulness, discernment, and the cessation of name-and-form.

snp3.8.blurb: Death and loss are inevitable, but grief is not.

snp2.12.blurb: Vaṅgīsa, the foremost poet among the Buddha’s disciples, praises the Buddha in verse.

snp-uragavagga.blurb: Twelve poems beginning with a set of similes comparing a liberated one with a serpent who sheds its skin. The poems are diverse in style and content, and appear to have been collected from different sources. This chapter includes many perennial favorites such as the Mettā Sutta on Love and the warnings of the Parābhava Sutta on downfalls.

snp-atthakavagga.blurb: This chapter, which has parallels in Chinese, and received an early commentary in the Niddesa, is often regarded as one of the earliest texts in the canon. Shorn of literary embellishments, it is direct and  powerful. A distinctive aspect is the critique of meaningless debates and attachments to views. The Attadaṇḍa Sutta gives an alternative account of the reasons for the Buddha’s going forth.

snp2.6.blurb: The Buddha encourages the monks to avoid monks who are evil in their desires.

snp3.7.blurb: Sela the brahman praises the Buddha to see how the latter responds to praise.

snp2.2.blurb: People are defiled, not by eating meat, but by engaging in evil conduct.

iti.blurb: 112 short discourses in mixed prose and verse, arranged in the Aṅguttara style of ascending numbered sets, from one to four. Alone among Buddhist texts, its survival is attributed not to the Saṅgha, but to a laywoman named Khujjuttarā. According to the Pali commentaries, she was a maid to the Queen of Kosambi, and memorized these teachings from the Buddha, earning her the title of the most learned of the laywomen disciples.

vv.blurb: The “Stories of Celestial Mansions” contains eighty-five stories in verse that illustrate the heavenly rewards of virtuous deeds, especially making offerings to the Buddha or the Saṅgha. It is a counterpart to the Petavatthu. These are late devotional texts with no direct counterparts in other collections.
